challenge.title: Task 51
challenge.description:
Conditional sentences often use the word if to describe a situation that will cause a particular result. They typically consist of two parts: the condition (the if part) and the result. For example:

If you study hard, you will pass the exam. (condition: studying hard; result: passing the exam)

In the dialogue, the expert uses a conditional sentence to explain the consequences of skipping breakfast.

question.text: What does the expert imply with his conditional sentence?

answers.answer: Eating breakfast causes you to feel sluggish later
answers.feedback: The conditional sentence relates to skipping breakfast, not eating it.

answers.answer: Skipping breakfast leads to compensating later by overeating or feeling sluggish
You can skip breakfast without any consequences
answers.feedback: The expert implies that skipping breakfast does have consequences.

answers.answer: Having breakfast makes you compensate by eating less later
answers.feedback: The focus is on the consequences of skipping breakfast, not having it.

dialogue.text: Another thing: don't skip breakfast. Breakfast gives you the energy to start the day.
If you skip it, you probably compensate later by eating too much or you feel sluggish in the morning.
